div.p: Monograph publication of Schenker's study of Beethoven's Fifth Symphony – the first of Schenker's four great full-length single-work studies written in the 1920s, the others being those of Brahms's Variations and Fugue on a Theme by Handel, Op. 24 (Tonwille Heft 8/9, 1924), Mozart's Symphony No. 40 in G minor (Meisterwerk II, 1926), and Beethoven's "Eroica" Symphony (Meisterwerk III, 1930).

Schenker wrote his study of Beethoven's Fifth Symphony between 1920 and late 1923, published first in three installments in Tonwille Heft 1 (1921), Heft 5 (1923; actually Feb 1924), and Heft 6 (1923; actually April 1924) over the fictitious imprint "Tonwille-Flugblätterverlag," and thereafter published together as a monograph over Universal Edition's own imprint [UE 7646].

The first approach by UE to discuss the possibility of monograph publication came on May 5, 1924 (diary, OJ 3/6, p. 2662), and the monograph was publicized at the back of Tonwille Heft 7 [=IV/1] (Jan–March 1924; actually Aug 1924) and Heft 8/9 [=IV/2–3] (April–Sept 1924; actually Nov 1924).
